'''Floyd Dixon''' (February 8, 1929 – July 26, 2006)<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p331/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Biography by Jason Ankeny |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=June 1, 2009}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[rhythm and blues]] [[pianist]] and [[singer]].

==Life and career==
Dixon was born '''Jay Riggins, Jr.''' in [[Marshall, Texas|Marshall]], [[Texas]], [[United States]].<ref name="AMG"/> He was influenced by [[blues]], [[gospel (music)|gospel]], [[jazz]] and [[country music]] growing up. His family moved to [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], [[California]] in 1942 and Dixon met his influence [[Charles Brown (musician)|Charles Brown]] there.<ref name="AMG"/>

Self-dubbed "Mr. Magnificent," Dixon signed a [[recording contract]] with [[Modern Records]] in 1949, specializing in [[jump blues]] and sexualized [[song]]s like "Red Cherries", "Wine Wine Wine", "Too Much Jelly Roll" and "Baby Let's Go Down to The Woods". Dixon replaced Brown on piano and vocals in the band [[Johnny Moore's Three Blazers]] in 1950 when Brown departed to start a solo career. The group recorded on [[Aladdin Records]].<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]]
| edition= 
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 106–107
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> Staying with the [[record label]], Dixon had a small [[hit record|hit]] under his own name in 1952 with "Call Operator 210".<ref name="russell"/>

Dixon switched to the [[Specialty Records]] [[record label|label]] in 1952, and the [[Atlantic Records]] subsidiary Cat Records in 1954. "[[Hey Bartender]]" (later [[cover version|covered]] by [[The Blues Brothers]]) and "Hole In The Wall" were [[hit single]]s during this time.

In the 1970s Dixon left the [[music industry]] for a quieter life in Texas, though he did occasional tours in the 1970s and 1980s.<ref name="russell"/> In 1984 he was commissioned to [[songwriter|write]] "Olympic Blues" for the [[1984 Summer Olympics]].<ref name="AMG"/>

In 1993, Dixon received a Pioneer Award from the [[Rhythm and Blues Foundation]].<ref name="AMG"/> In the mid-1990s, he secured a contract with [[Alligator Records]], releasing the critically acclaimed [[album]], ''Wake Up And Live''.<ref name="AMG"/>

On June 1 and 2, 2006, Dixon hosted a concert with [[Pinetop Perkins]] and [[Henry Gray (musician)|Henry Gray]], celebrating the intergenerational aspect of blues piano.  The band was led by [[Kid Ramos]] and included [[Larry Taylor]] and  Richard "Bigfoot" Innes.  [[Kim Wilson]], Fred Kaplan (from the Hollywood Blue Flames) and [[Lynwood Slim]] also performed.  This concert was filmed and was released March 6 2013 on HighJohn Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highjohn.com/ |title=Highjohn Records LLC - Home |publisher=Highjohn.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-06}}</ref> 

Dixon died in [[Orange County, California]] in July 2006, at the age of 77, from [[Renal failure|kidney failure]], having suffered with [[cancer]].<ref name="AMG"/>  A public memorial service was held at Grace Chapel, in the grounds of the [[Inglewood Park Cemetery]].
